narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Amazing course overall. My only critique is that occasionally organization around field trips was confusing; however, they provided an amazing learning experience, and I hope they are replicated in future years â I only wish there were more of them! It would also be very cool to go out and do 'volunteer' eradication work of some form for a day and gain a personal insight into the on-the-ground challenges of IAS management.
Both instructors were extremely warn, receptive, and gave great feedback

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: It is a discussion driven course, which was great, and everyone came to class prepared every week, making it extremely interesting.

Dynamic discussion and a great class atmosphere. You both did a wonderful job of keeping the conversation going and pushing us to think a little deeper. The guest speakers were also a strong component of this course -- talking to people about their research is always so different from simply reading a paper. The small class size and the wide scope of subject matter covered complemented each other well, in terms of moving quickly while effectively touching upon different topics.
Readings from primary literature were comprehensive and I felt that I understood the scholarly history of the topicEnjoyed the in-class discussions and presentations from fellow students
The material and the discussions. The class was organized as a discussion format, and it was perfect for the material covered. I felt that I learned a lot from this course!
I really enjoyed the class dicussions

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Expectations were not always clear for the various assignments, especially given that the timeline kept on shifting; similarly, we often didn't know what was going to happen on a field trip until we were out there and doing whatever it was that needed doing. Also, it occasionally got very competitive to get speaking time if you're not so good at jumping between comments; maintaining awareness of the different people in the class could help enable everyone to contribute to discussion.

This is pretty minor, but I found it frustrating that the field trips were scheduled so late in the semester. It also (I don't believe) wasn't made clear that field trips would be on Fridays when we signed up for the course. It can be really difficult for students to attend things on Fridays: since there are no classes on Fridays, all of our professors schedule field trips, exams, extra activities, etc. on Fridays, and then all of a sudden we have all these conflicts on Fridays!In the case of this class, I felt that the field trips were interesting, but I thought they should be "recommended," not mandatory. While I'm glad I went, I don't feel that they were essential for my learning in the course--and it might be better for everyone's schedule if making 1 or 2 of 3 required, instead of all of them!

comments: It is highly applicable to my interests

comments: Have done past research into invasive species and wanted to learn more about the issue
Because it it relevant to my academic and career interests

comments: Metand exceeded them! We learned so much, and this course will inform my perspective on other environmental issues.
Yes

yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: They were all good experiences, actually
Greater mastery of the material

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It is a great course and you learn a lot from it.

Take this course, do the readings and be an active participant in the class! This course was amazing because everyone in the room was invested in the discussion, and came from a different perspective, creating a quality learning experience in a hugely important field.

If you're interested in invasive species, definitely take the course! It's a great discussion focused class, and you will come away with a very good understanding of most of the major issues that have to do with invasive species! (They're a much bigger problem than you think...)
It is extremely valuable and gives a very different perspective on ecology and management issues than any other course I've taken at Yale. Definitely my favorite this semester.
Take it definitely!
